H0.text: Food is what animals cannot make for themselves, as they are heterotrophs.

H1.text: Fuel is what animals, as heterotrophs, cannot make their own.

H2.text: Energy is what animals cannot make for themselves, as heterotrophs.

H3.text: Habitat is what animals, as heterotrophs, cannot make themselves.

A4.text: Heterotrophs, organisms that obtain energy and carbon by consuming organic matter, are vital parts of Earth's biogeochemical cycles particularly in the carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur cycles.

A5.text: Heterotrophs are key players in the carbon cycle, acting as both consumers and decomposers.
